lines.text: You know, addressing envelopes ain't as tough as it's cracked up to be.
No?

No! There's a lot of money in it. I doped the whole thing out a while ago. At a dollar and a half a thousand, if I sell an envelope to everybody in the United States, I'd make a hundred and fifty thousand dollars!
That's swell. Have you figured out how long it's going to take you to do that?
Oh, um... About two-hundred and fifty years.
I had no idea there was such a future in it.

Listen, kid, did you ever hear of a game of pool that has to do with the eight ball? Well, the idea of the game is not to hit that particular ball, see? If you do - you lose. But if you land right behind it, you can't help yourself, can you? You've got to hit it. Well, that's the way it is when you get mixed up with a married man. You're always behind the eight ball. You *always* lose.
I thought a ride in the park would
[hiccups]
calm your nerves.
Well there's nothing wrong with my nerves.
No?
No.
Well maybe you'd come with me. I need the air.
Yeah? Well I'm giving you the air.
Her mother says she's earning 200 dollars a week now.
A week?
That's what she says.
Makes my 15 a week look kinda silly.
There's nothing silly about that.
You needn't make fun of your job. Fifteen dollars is a good salary nowadays.

[Sarcastically]
Yeah, swell!
What's up Cassie?
You better get yourself another soda jerker, Lem.
Why? What do you mean?
I'm going to New York.
Oh, go away, I hate blondes.
Well, I hate drunks; so, that makes us even.
What have you got against the world? It seems to be treating you all right.
I'm fed up. That's all. Fed up with - formal dinners, pompous butlers, and - and...
And blondes.
Say, was it a blonde that drove you to drink?
Oh, no. I don't need anybody to drive me to drink. I can do that myself.
It certainly must have been a wild party last night.
Oh, I don't know. I didn't stay there long. I ducked and spent the night in a speakeasy. I had to get away from those cackling women.
[Falls on Cassie's lap]
Oh, excuse me. I beg your pardon.
Well, don't tell me they were all blondes?
Did I say I hated blondes? Well, I was wrong! 'Cause I hate brunettes too! Yes, and redheads.
What have the poor things done to you?
Do you know what I'm going to do, the rest of my life?
No.
I'm going to spend the time looking for an honest woman. You think I'll ever find one?
No, never.
You're right! There ain't no such animal.
Well what are you doing home?
Job number three is now a thing of the past.
Yeah? What happened?
Oh, the Manager had a lot of brand new ideas. He tried to take my waist measurement.
Oh, I know. Wanted to see if you were gaining any weight, huh?
Yeah.

Say, Cass, you don't happen to know of a good man layin' around loose, do ya? A plumber or something? I'd grab the first one that came along so - I - wouldn't - have - to - type - these - silly - stupid - things!
Oh, you're always yelping about men, Dot!
Yeah, well that's my trouble. All I do is yelp. But, I never can get my clutches on one.
Oh, they give me a pain!
Oh, I met a new breed this morning.
Yeah, what's he like?
Rich, handsome, - and a sap! He was in the store when I had the scrap this morning. Brought me home in his car.
What happened? Did he make a pass at you?
No, he didn't even try to date me up! The conceded fool!
Well, what are you kicking about? Isn't that what you want?
Yeah, but a man doesn't have to be insulting, does he?
Well, goodbye slave. I'm gonna have my lunch in style!
Yeah and I hope you choke!
Listen, when you walk, forget you have hips. Let them take care of themselves - they always do. Look, here's the idea, add a little smile.
You're crazy about him, aren't you?
Ga-ga - and it's no good. If I ever thought I'd love him so violently, I'd dropped him the minute I felt it coming on. Take my advice, Cassie, never fall in love. It's terrible.

I was gonna throw this stuff out - but, you might as well eat it. Aw, there's one of the finest little weenies that ever graced a paper plate. It's a little shriveled from old age. But, of course, you can't have everything. And the baloney - well, its just baloney.
You know, you're quite a novelty. Most of the girls around here seem to spend their time competing to see who can get blotto first.
Well, you know, I like to get tight once in awhile.
Why?
Oh, it takes me to strange places, where I meet strange people. Like you - for instance.
Is that supposed to be a compliment?
Do you want to go out somewhere or prefer to sit around here and talk.
Sit around here and - talk? Can that be done?

Listen, if he'll take you, grab him while the grabbin's good! And in a little while, maybe he'll find what a heel he's been and marry you anyway. And if he don't, what's the odds? You'll have a beautiful apartment, plenty of clothes and pot full of Do-Re-Mi.
Oh, Cassie, don't get in my class.
Why shouldn't she get in your class? What's wrong with your class? Say you're a great one to be talkin' and you living in the lap of luxury.
Listen, Dot, I'd scrub floors if I could start all over again.
Awww! That's a lot of plain, ordinary hooey! And in the meantime you're living on Park Avenue, have a car of your own, and you eat at the Ritz. Well, all I can say is you're havin' a swell time!

Say, the trouble with you is, you've forgotten how awful it is to live in a dump like this. You don't know what it means to have to cut down on your food, so you can scrap together the rent or else old horse-face downstairs will throw you out on your what's-it. Say, listen, did you ever have to eat liverwurst seven days a week, cause you couldn't afford anything else? Well, try it sometime, you'll be nuts about it!
You've got to hang on to your self respect, Dot. And that's important.
Awww, what's your self respect when your hungry? It won't get you a porterhouse, will it?
So long, Dot.
Goodbye.
Look me up sometime, I'll show you life among the rich and miserable.
Says you!
I'm not sure I'm doing the right thing, Dot.
Awww, nertz! If you think it's right, it's right! That's the only way to look at it.
Say, when do I get my Bromo-Seltzer?
